verb.description: Bend (something flexible and relatively flat) over on itself so that one part of it covers another.
examples: she folded all her clothes and packed all her bags

verb.description: Cover or wrap something in (a soft or flexible material)
examples: a plastic bag was folded around the book

verb.description: (of an enterprise or organization) cease operating as a result of financial problems or a lack of support.
examples: the club folded earlier this year

noun.description: A form or shape produced by the gentle draping of a loose, full garment or piece of cloth.
examples: the fabric fell in soft folds

noun.description: An undulation or gentle curve of the ground; a slight hill or hollow.
examples: the house lay in a fold of the hills

noun.description: A line or crease produced in paper or cloth as the result of folding it.

phrases: they're holding four column inches above the fold
The Los Angeles Times ran the story on the 25th (front page below the fold) and used three microphotographs from the Science article.
But "The Washington Post" or "The New York Times" is not going to run a silly frivolous story above the fold.
Then fight to get your story on the front page, above the fold, with the big headline and a photo.
What reporters really want is their byline on the front page above the fold.
origin: Old English fald, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vaalt.
